title: On the compactification of concave ends

title_detail.value: On the compactification of concave ends

summary:
Let X be a complex manifold of dimension 2, which admits a strictly
plurisubharmonic function r which is proper as a function with values in the
intervall ]inf r, sup r[. We prove that the concave end of X can be
compactified, if and only if, the first cohomology of X is Hausdorff.

summary_detail.value:
Let X be a complex manifold of dimension 2, which admits a strictly
plurisubharmonic function r which is proper as a function with values in the
intervall ]inf r, sup r[. We prove that the concave end of X can be
compactified, if and only if, the first cohomology of X is Hausdorff.

author: Juergen Leiterer
fulltext:
arXiv:0808.4148v1 [math.CV] 29 Aug 2008

ON THE COMPACTIFICATION OF CONCAVE ENDS
MARTIN BRUMBERG AND JÜRGEN LEITERER

1. Introduction
1.1. Definition. We say that ρ : X → ]a, b[ is a 1-corona if:
a ∈ R ∪ {−∞}, b ∈ R ∪ {∞},
X is a complex manifold,
ρ is a strictly plurisubharmonic C ∞ -function defined on X and with values
in the open interval ]a, b[ such that the sets {α ≤ ρ ≤ β}, a < α < β < b,
are compacet.
We say that the concave end of a 1-corona ρ : X →]a, b[ can be compactified if X
b such that, for a < c < b,
is (biholomorphic to) an open subset of a complex space X
b
the set (X \ X) ∪ {a < ρ ≤ c} is compact.

The concave end of a 1-corona ρ : X →]a, b[ always can be compactified if
n := dim X ≥ 3. This was proved by Rossi [Ro] and Andreotti-Siu [AS]. For n = 2
this not true in general, as shown by a counterexample of Grauert, Andreotti-Siu
and Rossi [AS, Gr, Ro]. However, if the concave end of a 1-corona ρ : X →]a, b[ is
even hyperconcave (i.e. a = −∞), then this is again true also for dim X = 2. This
was proved by Marinescu-Dinh [MD].
The Andreotti-Vesentini separation theorem [AV] implies the following necessary
condition: If the concave end of a 1-corona ρ : X →]a, b[ can be compactified,
∞
-forms is closed
dim X ≥ 2, then H 1 (X) is Hausdorff, i.e. the space of exact C0,1
with respect to uniform convergence on compact sets together with all derivatives.
In the present paper we show that this condition is also sufficient. We prove:
1.2. Theorem. Let ρ : X →]a, b[ be a 1-corona such that H 1 (X) is Hausdorff, and
let n := dim X ≥ 2.
Then X can be embedded to C2n+1 .
Hence, by the Harvey-Lawson theorem [HaLa], the concave end of X can be
compactified.
1.3. Remark. In view of the counterexample of Grauert, Andreotti-Siu and Rossi
mentioned above, theorem 1.2 shows that theorem 2 in [Ra], which states that
H 1 (X) is Hausdorff for each 1-corona ρ : X →]a, b[ also for dim X = 2, cannot be
true.
The present paper is a development of the PhD thesis of the first author [Br],
where the following theorem is proved:
2000 Mathematics Subject Classification.
Keywords: embedding of complex manifolds, strictly psuedoconvex.
1

 2

MARTIN BRUMBERG AND JÜRGEN LEITERER

1.4. Theorem. Let ρ : X →]a,
 b[ ba a 1-corona, dim X ≥ 2. Assume, for some
a < t < b, H 1 {a < ρ < t} is Hausdorff. Then there exists ε > 0 such that
{t − ε < ρ < b} can be embedded to some CN .
Theorem 1.4 can be deduced as follows from theorem 1.2: Suppose the hypotheses of theorem 1.4 are satisfied. Then, by theorem 1.2, {a < ρ < t} can
be embedded to some CN . By the Harvey-Lawson theorem this implies that the
concave end of {a < ρ < t} and, hence, the concave end of X can be compactified.
By the Andreotti-Grauert theorem this further implies that H 1 (X) is Hausdorff.
Again using theorem 1.2, we conclude that X (and in particular {t − ε < ρ < b})
can be embedded to some CN . Note however that in [Br] a direct proof of theorem
1.4 is given, not using the compactification of the concave end.
The new contribution of the present paper is the observation that if ρ : X →]a, b[
is a 1-corona such that H 1 (X) is Hausdorff, then H 1 {a < ρ < t} is Hausdorff
for all a < t < b (see theorem 2.5 below). After that we could continue as in
[Br] to prove the following two assertions on the existence of "many" holomorphc
functions:
(A) The global holomorphic functions on X separate points.
(B) For each z ∈ X there exist n global holomorphic functions on X which
form a coordinate system at z.
From (A) and (B), the claim of theorem 1.2 then follows in the same way as in
the proof of the embedding theorem for Stein manifolds (see, e.g., theorem 5.3.6 in
[Ho]).
However, to prove (A) and (B) as in [Br], boundary estimates for the ∂-equation
are needed, which are well-known but nevertheless quite technical. To show that
this is not necessary, in the present paper we give another proof using only inner estimates for the ∂-equation. A similar construction can be found already in
[HL2] (section 23), where assertions (A) and (B) are deduced
 from certain stronger
hypothesis, which implies the Hausdorffness of H 1 {ρ < t} for each a < t < b.
Aknowledgement: We want to thank Genadi Henkin for the discussions during
the conference "Complex Analyis and Geometry" held from 23.06.08 to 29.06.08
in Bukarest (where the second autor gave a lecture on the PhD-thesis of the first
author). In particular, we are grateful for the hint that the methods proving the
embedability of Stein manifolds can be applied also to non-Stein manifolds, provided
properties (A) and (B) are already established.
2. Each H 1 ({ρ < t}) is Hausdorff if H 1 (X) is Hausdorff
2.1. Definition. Let Y be a complex manifold of complex dimension n.
∞
Then we denote by E p,q (Y ), 0 ≤ p, q ≤ n, the Fréchet space of Cp,q
-forms on Y
endowed with the topology of uniform convergence together with all derivatives on
the compact subsets of Y .
p,q
If K ⊆ Y is a compact set, then we denote by DK
(Y ) the subspace of E p,q (Y )
which consists of the forms with support in K, endowed with the same topology.
∞
By Dp,q (Y ) we denote the space all Cp,q
-forms on Y with compact support,
endowed with the Schwartz topology, i.e. the finest local convex topology such that,
p,q
for each compact set K ⊆ Y , the embedding DK
(Y ) → Dp,q (Y ) is continuous.
Recall the following well known fact from Serre duality [L]:

 ON THE COMPACTIFICATION OF CONCAVE ENDS

2.2. Proposition. Let Y be a complex manifold of dimension n. Then the space
∂E 0,0 (Y ) is closed in E 0,1 (Y ), if and only if, ∂Dn,n−1 (Y ) is closed in Dn,n (Y ).
We need also the following supplement to this (see theorem 2.7. in [LL]):
2.3. Proposition. Let Y be a complex manifold of dimension n. Then the space
∂Dn,n−1 (Y ) is closed in Dn,n (Y ), if and only if, for each compact set K ⊆ Y , the
n,n

(Y ) ∩ ∂Dn,n−1 (Y ) is closed in DK
(Y ).
Moreover, we shall use the following result from Andreotti-Grauert theory (see,
e.g., theorem 16.1 in [HL2]):
2.4. Proposition. Let ρ : X →]a, b[ be a 1-corona, and let a < c < b. Then each
∂-closed f ∈ E n,n−1 (X) with f ≡ 0 on {c < ρ < b} is ∂-exact.
Using these propositions, we now obtain:

3. Approximation
Here we prove the following theorem:
3.1. Theorem. Let ρ : X →]a, b[ be a 1-corona such that H 1 (X) is Hausdorff, and
let a < t < b. Then each holomorphic function defined in a neighborhood of {ρ ≤ t}
can be approximated uniformly on {ρ ≤ t} by holomorphic functions defined on X.

 4

MARTIN BRUMBERG AND JÜRGEN LEITERER

We prove this by means of Grauert's bump method, similarly as in the case of
strictly pseudoconvex manifolds (see, e.g., the proof of theorem 2.12.3 in [HL1]),
although, in distinction to strictly pseudoconvex manifolds, here the ∂-equation
not always can be solved. This is possible, because for the
 bump method only the
Hausdorffness (and not the vanishing) of all H 1 {ρ < t} , a < t < b, is needed.

3.2. Definition. A collection


ρ : X →]a, b[ , φ : X →]a, b[ , c , (U ; z1 , . . . , zn )

will be called a Grauert bump if:
(a) ρ : X →]a, b[ and φ : X →]a, b[ are strictly pseudoconvex coronas1 such
that {ρ ≤ c} ⊆ {φ ≤ c};
(b) U is a relatively compact open subset of X, and z1 , . . . , zn are holomorphic
coordinates defined in a neighborhood of U such that U is a ball with
respect to these coordinates and ρ = φ in a neighborhood of X \ U .
3.3. Lemma. Let


ρ : X →]a, b[ , φ : X →]a, b[ , c , (U ; z1 , . . . , zn )

be a Grauert bump. Then each holomorphic function defined in a neighborhood
of {ρ ≤ c} can be approximated uniformly on {ρ ≤ c} by holomorphic functions
defined in a neighborhood of {φ ≤ c}.
Proof. Let a holomorphic function f in a neighborhood of {ρ ≤ c} be given. Choose
ε > 0 so small that


ρ : X →]a, b[ , φ : X →]a, b[ , c + ε, (U ; z1 , . . . , zn )

is still a Grauert bump and f is holomorphic in a neighborhood of {ρ ≤ c + ε}.
As U is convex with respect to the coordinates z1 , . . . , zn and the function ρ is
plurisubharmonic in a neighborhood of U , the set U ∩ {ρ ≤ c + ε} is polynomially
convex with respect to z1 , . . . , zn (see, e.g., theorem 4.3.2 in [Ho] or theorem 2.7.1.
in [HL1]). Therefore we can find a sequence of holomorphic functions uν defined
on a neighborhood of U , which converges to f uniformly on U ∩ {ρ ≤ c + ε}.
Since ρ = φ in a neighborhood of X \ U , we can find a relative compact open
subset U ′ of U such that ρ = φ outside U ′ . Choose a C ∞ -function χ on X such
that χ ≡ 1 in U ′ and χ ≡ 0 in a neighborhood of X \ U . Setting

Theorem 3.1 now is an immediate consequence of the preceding lemma and the
following lemma:
3.4. Lemma. Let ρ : X →]a, b[ be a strictly pseudoconvex corona, and let a < t < b.
Then there exists a sequence

The latter lemma follows easily from the fact that a C 2 -small pertubation of a
strictly plurisubharmonic function is again such a function. We omit the proof,
which is the same as in the case of a strictly pseudoconvex manifold (see, e.g.,
lemma 2.12.4 in [HL1] or lemma 12.3 in [HL2] and the subsequent remark).

MARTIN BRUMBERG AND JÜRGEN LEITERER

4. Proof of theorem 1.2
In this section ρ : X →]a, b[ is a 1-corona such that H 1 (X) is Hausdorff. As
already observed in the introduction, we only have to prove that conditions (A) and
(B) are satisfied. To prove this, let two different points ξ, η ∈ X and a holomorphic
tangential vector θ of X at ξ be given. It is sufficient to show that:
(A') There exists a holomorphic function f on X such that f (ξ) 6= f (η).
(B') There exists a sequence of holomorphic functions gν on X such that ∂gν (ξ)
converges to θ.
We may assume that ρ(ξ) ≥ ρ(η). Choose a system z = (z1 , . . . , zn ) of holomorphic coordinates defined in a neighborhood U of ξ such that η 6∈ U , z(ξ) = 0 and
z(U ) contains the unit ball. Let
